title: Fossil Vertebrates From the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, Coahuila, Mexico, and the Distribution of Late Campanian (Cretaceous) Terrestrial Vertebrate Faunas
abstract: The Cerro del Pueblo Formation, Coahuila, Mexico, includes the southernmost Upper Cretaceous non-marine vertebrate assemblage in North America. Previously, the only well-documented vertebrates were dinosaurs, mainly ornithopods, and turtles. Recent work on the Cerro del Pueblo Formation has resulted in the recovery of a good sample of small tetrapods from different microvertebrate localities in the upper part of this Late Cretaceous unit of north of Mexico. Material from these sites augments the faunal list from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. New amphibian taxa here described include the first occurrences of frogs and salamanders. Newly recovered reptiles represent five families of lizards; Anguidae, Teiidae, Necrosauridae, Varanidae, and Helodermatidae; two species of aniliid snakes (one of them new); a new genus and species of marine turtle from the tribe Bothremydini; the brevirostrine crocodile Brachichampsa; and the most southerly occurrence of a long snouted crocodile. New dinosaurs reported here include a ceratopsian and members of five theropod families: two dromaeosaurids including an indeterminate genus and the velociraptorine vi Saurornitholestes, the small theropods Troodon and Richardoestesia, an ornithomimid, and a large tyrannosaurid. The ornithomimid is represented by a partial skeleton and a new genus and species, Saltillomimus rapidus, is erected on the basis of this material. Mammals are represented by two kinds of marsupials, Turgidodon cf. T. russelli, and Pediomys cf. P. elegans, and generically indeterminate multituberculates of the families Taeniolabidoidae and Cimolomydae. The fauna of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation is compared with the fauna from contemporaneous formations from further north, particularly the Aguja and Javelina formations of Texas, to give a more regional overview of the faunas of the southern portion of North America during the Late Cretaceous. The differences are shown in the diversity and number plants associated to new taxa of hadrosaurs and ceratopsians and the absence of sauropods in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. Differences in the faunal composition of the Cerro del Pueblo and Aguja formations indicate that paleocological complexity was present in southern regions of North America during the Late Campanian. Thus together these formations can be considered to characterize the southern-most region of North America.

body_text.text: Page INTRODUCTION A significant amount of provincialism is present in the Late Cretaceous vertebrate assemblages of North America (Sankey et al., 2005; Lehman et al., 2006) . Those from more southerly latitudes are of particular interest because faunas of southern North America remain inadequately known. Thus, the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, a unit of late Campanian age in northeast Mexico that contains abundant vertebrate fossils (Kirkland et al, 2000) , is important for interpreting patterns of distribution in vertebrate assemblages of the Late Cretaceous. This study is focused on the smaller vertebrates of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, and therefore provides a more complete understanding of the faunas within the formation.

The Cerro del Pueblo Formation is the basal unit of the Difunta Group. The Difunta Group was defined by Murray et al. (1962) to include all strata between the Parras Shale to the top of the Rancho Nuevo Formation within the Parras Basin (Fig. 1) . McBride et al. (1974) expanded the definition of the group to include the overlying formations above the Parras Shale in the La Popa Basin. Therefore the entire Difunta Group is exposed along the Parras-La Popa Basins southwest of Saltillo to western Nuevo Leon, Mexico (McBride et al., 1974; Ye, 1997; Lawton et al., 2001) . A thickness of about 4000 meters of sediment in the Parras Basin suggests a high rate of sediment input (Weidie and Murray 1967 Mexico (Dillman and Casey, 1985) . It contains 5,500 m of Mesozoic-Lower Tertiary sequences that cover an area of 30,000 square kilometers from west of Monterrey, Nuevo

Leon, to east of Torreon, Coahuila (Weidie and Murray, 1967) . The basin shape is irregular ( Fig. 1 ). Stratigraphic and structural features separate the Parras Basin into western, central and eastern parts. The focus of this study is the exposures in the central part of the basin. This part contains alternating marine and terrestrial rocks, which are thrown into open, elongate compressional folds (Weidie and Murray, 1967; McBride et al., 1974; Kirkland et al., 2000) .

The Parras Formation is 1500 m thick and is exposed in the Parras and La Popa basins. Laterally the Parras Formation is a lithic continuation of and partially equivalent to the Mendez Formation (Murray et al., 1962) , which is a marine unit that crops out west of Nuevo Leon and Tamaulipas. The Parras Formation (Santonian-Campanian) is time equivalent to the upper part of the Ojinaga Formation of west Texas, and both preserve deposits of similar character (Weidie et al., 1972; McBride et al., 1974; Lehman, 1997) .

The Campanian sediments of the Parras Formation in the central part of the Parras Basin are black, calcareous marine shales and siltstones (Weidie and Murray, 1967) . The vertebrate fauna is represented by Ischyryza mira, Squalicorax kaupi, Scapanorynchus texanus, and unidentified marine amniotes (Aguillon and Espinosa, 1997) . No terrestrial
vertebrates have yet been recovered.

The Parras Formation is overlain by the Difunta Group (Fig. 1) . This unit was initially described as the Difunta Formation (Imlay 1936 (Imlay , 1937 but was revised as a group composed of seven formations in the Parras Basin and another 6 formations in the La Popa Basin (Murray et al.,1962) . The Difunta Group reaches a maximum thickness north of Saltillo, where the seven formations that form the group in the Parras basin are exposed (Weidie et al., 1967) . The Group is about 4,000 m thick and composed of red and green non-marine and brackish-water sandstone and shale alternating with gray to black, brackish water and marine, calcareous sandstone and shale (Weidie et al., 1967) . Imlay (1936 Imlay ( , 1937 and Murray et al. (1962) interpreted the group as consisting of "delta and coastal plain deposits with fresh and brackish water lake and marsh deposits and rare marine spillover lobe deposits."

The age of the Difunta Group has been variously interpreted. Invertebrates have suggested a Campanian to Eocene age (Murray et al., 1960 (Murray et al., ,1962 Weidie and Murray, 1967; Vega and Perrilliat, 1992; Kirkland and Aguillon, 1995; Kirkland et al., 2000; Perrilliat et al., 2008) . Murray et al. (1962) (Imlay, 1936; 1937) . Later studies considered the Difunta Group to be Campanian to Paleocene in the Parras Basin (Murray et al., 1959 (Murray et al., , 1960 (Murray et al., , 1962 and
Maastrichtian to Eocene in the La Popa Basin (Lawton et al., 2001 (Lawton et al., , 2009 Perrillat et al., 2008; VegaVera et al., 1991) .

The Cerro del Pueblo Formation, the focus of this study, is the basal and the most productive unit in terms of vertebrates and fossil plants in the Difunta Group. It crops out only in the western and central part of the Parras Basin (Murray et al., 1962; McBride et al., 1974) . The original type section was located northwest of Saltillo on a small hill named Cerro del Pueblo. West of Saltillo, the formation reaches a maximum thickness of 500 m. This area has since been covered by housing and commercial development, and a new type section north of Saltillo was designated by Eberth et al. (2004) .

Formation; the contact is gradational defined by a basal marginal-marine sandstone. The Cerro del Pueblo Formation is laterally equivalent to the upper part of the wave dominated Muerto Formation of the eastern Parras and La Popa Basins (McBride et al., 1974) , and to the shallow marine San Miguel and Olmos-Escondido formations of the Sabinas Basin in northern Coahuila (Murray et al., 1962) . The Cerro del Pueblo Formation is overlain by the terrestrial red beds of the Cerro Huerta Formation (Murray et al., 1962; McBride et al., 1974) . McBride et al. (1974) and Wolleben (1977) suggested that the oldest strata from Cerro del Pueblo are in the western part of the Parras Basin.

body_text.section: The Cerro del Pueblo Formation conformably overlies the marine Parras

body_text.text: The Cerro del Pueblo Formation consists of gray mudstones, sandstones, and siltstones of deltaic and lacustrine origin (Murray et al., 1962; Weidie and Murray, 1967; and McBride et al., 1974) . Siderite nodules, septaria, and ripple marks are the most common sedimentary structures found in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation.
body_text.section: The Cerro del Pueblo Formation conformably overlies the marine Parras

body_text.text: Charophytes from the Difunta Group were first reported by Peck and Forester (1979) , who identified Platychara perlata. Charophyte algae occur in several stratigraphic intervals within the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, including Rincon Colorado, a locality in which vertebrates where also collected. Because charophytes are strictly non-marine they indicate these intervals were deposited in freshwater environments.
body_text.section: Flora of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation

body_text.text: The taxonomic identification of the charophytes from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation include two taxa; Platychara sp. and Porochara gildemeisteri (Fig. 2) .
body_text.section: Flora of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation

body_text.text: Porochara gildemeisteri was known previously only from Late Maastrichtian deposits in the Javi Chico, Argentina and Peru (Jaillard et al., 1993) . Thus, the occurrence of this species in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation extends its geographic range. It also suggests that either the Cerro del Pueblo in the Rincon Cololado area is Maastricthian in age, or the stratigraphic range of this species in North America extended to the Campanian, or the age assignment in South America is too young.
body_text.section: Flora of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation

body_text.text: The Cerro del Pueblo Formation contains a diverse floral record composed of monocot and dicot angiosperms, both represented by isolated seeds, fruits, wood fragments, flower impressions, and leaves (Rodriguez de la Cevallos-Ferriz, 1994, 1998; Calvillo-Canadell, and Cevallos-Ferriz., 2007; Estrada-Ruiz and Cevallos-Ferriz, 2007; Cevallos-Ferriz et al., 2008) (Table 3 ). This floral component suggest tropical to subtropical conditions for the Cerro del Pueblo Formation.
body_text.section: Flora of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation

body_text.text: The age of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation was initially interpreted as being within the Late Campanian Exogyra ponderosa zone (Murray, et al.; 1962; Weidie and Murray 1967; Wolleben, 1977) on the basis of invertebrates, especially Exogyra costata and Exogyra ponderosa. The known invertebrates from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation are listed in Table 1 . The presence of the ammonite Sphenodiscus was considered an anomaly because elsewhere this occurs in sediments of Maastrichtian age. Cobban (1993) suggested that this genus is endemic to northern Mexico in the Campanian and extends northward during the Maastrichtian (Murray et al., 1960; Kirkland et al., 1994) .
In a regional chronostratigraphic study, Wolleben (1977) used Exogyra ponderosa
and Exogyra costata, to distinguish the Parras Formation from the Cerro del Pueblo
Formation. However, formations should not be distinguished on fossil ranges.
Moreover, subsequent work has shown that these species are present both the Cerro del Pueblo and Parras formations, although it is more abundant in the Cerro del Pueblo
Formation.

Paleomagnetic studies indicate that the Cerro del Pueblo Formation in the Saltillo area was deposited during magnetozones 32n.3r-32n.2n (Eberth et al., 2004) . Correlation of this range within the combined Western Interior ammonite biozones B. reesidei to B.
jenseni indicates a maximum absolute age of 72.5 Ma, and thus is Late Campanian in age (Eberth et al., 2004) .

The Cerro Huerta Formation is restricted to the Parras Basin and overlies the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. The type section is 10 km southwest of Saltillo where it reaches a maximum thickness of 978 m. The contact with the underlying Cerro del
Pueblo is conformable and gradational (McBride et al., 1974; Soegeeard et al., 2003) .

This formation is non-marine in origin and is dominated by redbeds. Fossils reported from the Cerro Huerta Formation include petrified wood, charophytes and fragmentary dinosaur bones (Murray et al., 1962) . The stratigraphic level and identification of the charophytes is not documented. The dinosaur remains in the Cerro Huerta Formation are uncommon; they are fragmentary and highly abraded pieces of bone that give little additional information.

The Cañon del Tule Formation crops out in the central and eastern part of the Parras Basin and consists of interbedded sandstone and subordinate siltstone and shale (Soegaard et al., 2003) (Fig. 1) . It is 600 m thick north of Saltillo (Murray 1962) (2006) described and compared the freshwater turtles of the Cerro del Pueblo to the ones from Pelillal and pointed out that they are part of the Muerto Formation. However the geology of that area indicates that this fauna is in fact younger in age and occurs within the Cañon del Tule Formation (Ye, 1997; Lawton et al 2001 Lawton et al , 2009 Soegaard et al., 2003) . Thus the small vertebrates from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation remain undocumented. amphicoelous vertebra, differences in the outlines of cotyles on vertebrae, and the form of the anterior and posterior cotyles (Gardner, 2000) . SEPCP 9/741 is referred to Scapherpetontidae on the basis of centrum shape. The centrum of SEPCP 9/741 is deeply amphicoelous and spool shaped in ventral view. The anterior portion of the neural arch is broken off. The posterior and anterior cotyles are rounded and concave. The ventral keel is bent slightly laterally due to distortion (Fig. 4 ). SEPCP 9/741 is referred to the genus Lisserpeton because it has rounded cotyles and the cotyle opening is shallow compared to the centra of Scapherpeton.

Discussion. -Scapherpetont salamanders have distinctive vertebra. The trunk vertebrae of Scapherpeton have posterior and anterior cotyles that are teardrop-shaped and the cotyle opening is deep (Fig 4 B ) (Estes, 1969d) . In Lisserpeton, trunk vertebrae are deeply amphicoelous and have more rounded cotyles (Estes, 1965) . Lisserpeton has more delicate skeletal construction compared to Scapherpeton and Piceoerpeton (Holman, 2006) . The trunk vertebrae are unknown for Irvinetriton and Piceoerpeton is considered a derived form of Lisserpeton (Estes, 1969d; Naylor and Krause, 1981; Naylor, 1983; Garner, 2000) . Scapherpetontids are restricted to North America. The record of this group is from the Late Cretaceous to Early Eocene (Estes, 1965 (Estes, ,1969 Naylor and Krause, 1981 Wyoming. (Estes 1965 (Estes , 1969d Naylor and Krause, 1981; Gardner, 2000) . Thus SEPCP 9/741 is the first record of salamanders in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation.
Order ANURA Family Indet.
Locality.-La Parrita, General Cepeda Coahuila, Mexico.
Referred specimens.-SEPCP 9/590 vertebra, SEPCP 9/588 and SEPCP 9/589 centra, SEPCP 9/733 radioulna, SEPCP 9/583, and SEPCP 9/584 tibiofibulae.

Description.-The vertebra (SEPCP 9/590) has a spool-like centrum in ventral view. The centrum is amphicoelous and oval in cross section with the surface facing the neural canal flattened. A small medial depression shows the centrum to be the notochordal.

The neural canal is large and the walls of the neural arch are thin . A second procoelous vertebra, SEPCP 9/589, lacks the neural arch. The oval centrum is concave anteriorly for the reception of the preceding vertebra and convex posteriorly ( Fig. 5D ). In addition to vertebrae, fused hollow long bone elements are clearly anuran. SEPCP 9/733 is the distal end of the radioulna, which differs from the distal tibiofibula, SEPCP 9/583 and SEPCP 9/584, in that the distal end of the radius and ulna are separated by a relatively deeper groove, and the radius and ulna are of different lengths so the distal end of the element has a stepped appearance. The tibiale and fibulare have flat ends . In transverse view the diaphysis has an 8-shape. These bones are too fragmentary and undiagnostic to be identified further.

Discussion.-Presacral vertebrae differentiate broad taxonomic groups of anurans (Storer and Usinger, 1957) . Opisthocoelous vertebrae are characteristic of Discoglossidae, Xenopidae and Pipidae, thus eliminating those families from consideration with respect to these specimens. The radioulnae and tibiofibulae of anurans are distinctive in being fused, and these elements further indicate the presence of neobatrachians in the fauna of Referred specimen.-SEPCP 9/739, maxilla fragment preserving a posterior tooth; SEPCP 9/587, isolated posterior maxillary tooth.

Description.-SEPCP 9/739 is a small fragment of maxilla with a single tooth. The tooth is subacrodont with a large suboval base. The tooth crown is transversely-bicuspid with six cusps, two primary and four accessory. Three cusps are aligned on the lingual side as well as on the labial side. The central pair of cusps is the largest and the tallest. A second upper molar SEPCP 9/587, collected from a second, stratigraphically higher in the section at the La Parrita area, has a multicuspid crown with the central pair of cusps united by a V-shape ridge ( Fig. 6 ).

Discussion.-A lizard belonging to the Teiidae in having extensive cementum on the tooth base (Estes et al., 1988) . It is refered to Peneteious because it has maxillary teeth with large bases and multicuspid crowns with up to six cusps arranged in three parallel transverselly oriented pairs where the central one is the largest and have a V-shape blade (Nydam et al 2000) . Peneteius aquilonious has distinctive mammal-like tooth morphology in the sense of being expanded and multicusped. SEPCP 9/739 shares with the fossil teiids Bicuspidon, Polyglyphanodon, Paraglyphanodon, and Dicothodon a transverse tooth orientation and medially expanded crowns (Estes, 1969a; Nydam, 1999; Nydam et al., 2000; Nydam and Cifelli, 2005) . It differs from Polyglyphanodon and Bicuspidon in having posterior maxillary teeth with multicuspid crowns.
Polyglyphanodon and Peneteius have a transversely oriented central blade on the teeth.
The central blade is shallow between the lingual and labial cusps in Polyglyphanodon while in Peneteius it is notched (Nydam and Cifelli, 2005 ).

There are two described species of Peneteius. Estes (1969a Estes ( , 1969c Referred specimens.-SEPCP 9/714 right dentary fragment with four tooth positions, SEPCP 9/640 and SEPCP 9/641 isolated body osteoscutes.

Description.-The dentary is referred to Odaxosaurus because it has medially expanded teeth with squared and wrinkled crowns lingually and labially (Estes, 1964) . A fragment from the anterior part of a right dentary preserves three complete teeth and space for one more ( Fig. 7 A- (Gilmore, 1928; Gao and Fox, 1996) . Two species of the Odaxosaurus are currently recognized, O. piger from the late Maastrichtian and O.

priscus from the middle Campanian, both from the Judith River Group of Alberta (Gao and Fox, 1996) . The teeth of these two species differ in size, spacing and the development of striations on the crowns. In O. priscus, 4 teeth occupy a space of 5.3 mm, while in specimens of O. piger of the same size 5 teeth occupy this space (Gilmore, 1928 (Estes, 1964) , although it is present in other anguids, such as Ophisaurus hallensis (late Eocene), the early member of the genus Ophisaurus, and extant forms (Meszoely and Ford, 1976 Referred specimens.-SEPCP 9/582 right jaw fragment with a marginal tooth preserved.
SEPCP 9/717, and SEPCP 9/718 dorsal vertebrae.

Description.-SEPCP 9/582 is a fragment of the posterior part of a left dentary, containing a single tooth identified as Parasaniwa because the base of the tooth has infolded dentine, which produce striations, the tooth is unicuspid, trenchant and recurved (Estes et al., 1988) . The dentary is lightly built and the labial surface is smooth. The intramandibular septum is fused to the ventral border. The Meckelian groove is shallow mediolaterally. A small oval nutrient foramen is present labially below the tooth. The tooth is pleurodont and strongly compressed medio-laterally. The crown does not show serrations, but well-defined striations are present on the basal part of the tooth. The tooth base is round. A small foramen is present lingually at the base of the tooth (Fig. 8 A-C).

In addition to the jaw fragment, two well-preserved dorsal vertebrae (SEPCP 9/717 and 718) have been recovered from La Parrita microsites. In SEPCP 9/717 and SEPCP 9/718 the ventral surface of the centra are flat and lacking the sagittal ridge observed in other lizards (Fig. 9) . In ventral view the centra are conical with a distinctive constriction on SEPCP 9/717. The condyle is small and oval. The synapophyses are rounded and small. The neural canal is trifoliate. The zygosphene is small. It lacks prezygaphophyses.

Discussion.-Parasaniwa is a fossil lizard restricted to North America. The type specimen is from the Lance Formation (Late Maastrichtian) of Wyoming (Gilmore, 1928) . The oldest record is from the Campanian Judith River Group of Alberta, Canada (Gao and Fox, 1996; Peng et al., 2001 ). It has also been reported from the Kaiparowits Formation in Utah (Eaton et al., 1999) .

Specimen SEPCP 9/582 is referred to Parasaniwa because of the strongly compressed marginal teeth lacking serrations. It differs from the helodermatid Paraderma in lacking a venom groove and in that the crown is more strongly compressed. SEPCP 9/717 and SEPCP 9/718 are also referred to Parasaniwa because they have a tapered centrum, weak diapophyses and less developed zygantra and zygosphene compared to vertebrae of helodermatids and the fossil Paraderma bogerti (Hoffstter and Gasc, 1969; Gao and Fox, 1996) . The occurrence of Parasaniwa in the
Cerro del Pueblo extends the geographic range of this genus since previously the most southerly occurrence was in the Kaiparowits Formation of Utah (Eaton et al., 1999) .
Locality.-La Parrita, General Cepeda Coahuila, Mexico.
Referred specimens.-SEPCP 9/630 and SEPCP 9/734, isolated osteoderms.

Description.-SEPCP 9/ 630 and SEPCP 9/734 are both elongate osteoderms with a strong median ridge and a dorsal surface ornamented with small pits. The ventral surface is flat and unornamented ( Fig. 8 E-D) .

Discussion.-SEPCP 9/630 and SEPCP 9/734 are interpreted as scutes from a necrosaurid lizard because they are similar to the osteoscutes of Necrosaurus in being keeled and oval, with a surface ornamented by fine pits and ridges (Estes, 1983 Discussion.-Paraderma bogerti it is considered the earliest known member of Helodermatidae (Pregill et al., 1986) . The holotype a left maxillare, was collected from the Lance Formation of Wyoming (Gilmore, 1928) . Material recovered from the Scollard and Frenchman formations in Canada provides information on the cervical and dorsal vertebrae (Gao and Fox, 1996) . The dorsal vertebrae have a very distinctive centrum shape of helodermatid type. The centrum is less tapered, a condyle with poorly developed rim. (Gao and Fox, 1996) . SEPCP 9/631 has a small, less tapered centrum Palaeosaniwa, SEPCP 9/633-634, are both large and have a neural canal that is very short and trifoliate in shape. The centra are compressed, the cotyle is oblique so it faces strongly ventrally. Both specimens lack a condyle. In ventral view, the centra are tapered strongly, in contrast with the centra of Paraderma, which are more parallel sided (Gao and Fox, 1996) . The centra are short relative to their width, as in Palaeosaniwa canadensis but in contrast to Parasaniwa wiomingensis. SEPCP 9/633-634 are referred
to Palaeosaniwa canadensis because of the large size of the vertebra with centra shorter relative to their width.

The humerus, SEPCP 9/645, consists of the distal epiphysis, which is strongly expanded. It has well-ossified condyles and an ectepicondylar foramen. The ectepicondylar canal is long. It runs from the posterior surface of the humerus to emerge on the ventral surface lateral to the ulnar condyle. In ventral view the intercondylar groove is deep, dividing the radial and ulnar condyles. The ulnar and radial condyles are well preserved. The radial condyle is set at an angle relative to the long axis of the shaft of the humerus. The radial condyle is 40% larger than the ulnar condyle. The ulnar condyle is set parallel to the axis of the shaft (Fig. 10 ).

SEPCP 9/645 is identified as Palaeosaniwa because of similarities with a right humerus of Palaeosaniwa canadensis in collections of the University of Alberta Laboratory of Vertebrate Paleontology (UALVP). The two specimens are about the same size and are from a varanoid lizard that is much larger than Parasaniwa. Palaeosaniwa canadensis is the largest and most abundant varanoid of the Campanian Judith River Group in Canada (Gilmore, 1928; Gao and Fox, 1996) . The humeri from Mexico and

Canada have a similar position of the ectepicondylar foramen and canal. This differs from extant species of Varanus where the ectepicondylar foramen is located more proximal to the radial and ulnar condyles and the canal is much shorter. Gao and Fox (1996) and elliptical in shape. The centrum becomes narrow posteriorly. The condyle is well ossified and elliptical (2.9 mm wide; 2 mm high). It is strongly oblique when seen in lateral view and the condylar rim is well differentiated. The neck of the condyle is constricted. The cotyle is deep and is slightly wider than the zygosphene. A hypapophysis is absent and the neural canal is smaller than the cotyle (Fig. 11 ). There is no hemal keel. The subcentral foramina on the ventral surface are laterally placed midway along the centrum. The right subcentral foramen is small but the left one is wide, oval, longer, and deeper than the right.

The trifoliate neural canal is slightly wider than the cotyle. The neural arch is coossified with the centrum and its lamina is straight in posterior view. The lamina is broad and short. The posterior margin of the neural arch lacks a median notch. The neural spine is represented by a low ridge on the neural arch, behind the zygosphene. The height of the ridge is low relative to the length of the neural spine. The ventral surface of the zygosphene is slightly concave and the dorsal surface is straight. The roof is thicker than the cotylar rim. The articular facets of the zygosphene are oval and elongate. They face ventrolaterally at an angle of 45°. The zygantrum is wide (3.6 mm) with mediodorsally facing facets and no evidence of a zygantral foramen.

The zygapophyses are oriented laterally. The prezygapophyseal articular surface is obovate. The left prezygapophysis is 1.9 mm wide and has an inclination of 30° with no accessory process evident. Parapophyseal and diapophyseal facets are well preserved on both sides. The diapophyseal facet is rounded. Snake material has been recovered by dry screening at La Parrita microsite (SEPCP 9/627 and SEPCP 9/628). This material is fragmentary although the shape of the condyle and centrum allows them to be recognized as a coniophid (Fig. 12 , C-E).
Discussion. (Marsh, 1892; Gilmore 1938; Estes 1976; Fox, 1975; Armstrong-Ziegler, 1978; Gardner and Cifelli, 1999) and in Africa by

Coniophis dadiebus (Werner and Rage, 1994; Rage and Werner, 1999) . Eocene taxa include C. carinatus and C. platycarinatus in the Northern Hemisphere, and possibly fragmentary material from South America and Europe (Hecht, 1959; Rage, 1981; Gardner and Cifelli, 1999 and in having suprapygal (Gaffney et al, 2006) . with carapace of medium size, oval with length greater than width, moderately high domed, nuchal width greater than length, but less than 2 times, nuchal embayment absent, 1st costal twice as long as the 2nd costal, neural series includes six neurals , peripheral 1 has wide contact with costal 1. Plastron with posterior lobe shorter than the bridge, and with nearly parallel margins. Derived in having axillary and inguinal buttresses that are strongly developed, vertical plates with swollen medial ends forming pillars that extend between the carapace and plastron.
Xiphiplastral notch shallow or absent.

Description.-SEPCP 61/719, and SEPCP 9/752 are the two best preserved shells. portion of the nuchal. The neurals are regular, coffin-shaped elements, except for the first, which is rectangular, and the sixth, which is pentagonal rather than hexagonal. The marginal bones are mostly not preserved except as impressions (Fig. 13 A) . In ventral view the plastron lacks the anterior lobe but the hyoplastron, mesoplastron, hypoplastron, and a small portion of the xiphiplastral bones are distinct ( Fig. 13 B) . The mesoplastron is a shield-shaped element restricted to the lateral part of the plastron. The co-ossified pelvis is visible in posterior view. The pelvis was connected by sutures to the posterior lobe of the plastron. On the preserved xiphiplastron only the pubic scar is visible.

In SEPCP 9/752 there are 6 neurals and 8 costals. The suprapygal is roughly triangular in shape. The plastron is nearly complete and well preserved. The anterior lobe is short and rounded. The posterior lobe is large compared to the anterior lobe, with nearly parallel margins. The xiphiplastron is longer than wide. Both the pubic and ischiac sutural surfaces are visible. The pubic scar is oval but not elongated. The ischiac scar is triangular (Fig. 13 ). The edge of the xiphiplastral bones is rounded. SEPCP 61/753 is a carapace that shows a trapezoidal nuchal wider than long (Fig. 13 ).
Discussion.-Bothremydid turtles of the Cerro del Pueblo are commonly preserved as complete shells. Preserved shells of this group of turtles range from 5 to 25 cm in length.

Based on proportions of the preserved parts of the body observed in eight specimens recovered from la Parrita and las Aguilas a complete reconstruction of the carapace is possible. The shells also share a regular pattern of 6 neurals that are coffin-shaped and hexagonal, with the exception of the neural six, which is pentagonal. There is only one suprapygal, roughly triangular in shape. The nuchal is hexagonal, wider than long, with no notch. There are seven costal bones in the carapace. The plastron anterior lobe is wide and short. The posterior lobe is larger compared to the anterior lobe but smaller than the bridge. The posterior lobe is slightly tapering posteriorly. Taphosphyini (Gaffney and Zangerel, 1968; Gaffney et al., 2006 SEPCP 61/719 and SEPCP 9/751 have an anterior lobe of the plastron that is short and wide as in Bothremydini. They resemble Foxemys in having 6 neurals, with the first being the longest, and in having a first costal of similar proportions (Tong et al., 1998; Gaffney et al., 2006) (Fig. 14) . In the plastron the posterior lobe is nearly parallel, and the location of the pubic and ischiac scars are closer to the suture of the xiphiplastral bones. Posadachelys cerropueblensis shares with Taphrosphys six neurals, large size of the bridge and nearly parallel sides of the posterior lobe (Gaffney et al., 2006) . They share with Chedighaii the shape of the nuchal, but not the embayment and 2-4 short costals (Gaffney et al., 2006) . SEPCP 61/719 and SEPCP 9/751 share symplesiomorphies with both bothremydid tribes. Posadachelys cerropueblensis differs from Foxemys, Chedighaii, and Taphrosphys in having a high-domed shell, and a welldeveloped buttress with expanded pillar-like ends. It also differs in the size and shape of the pubic and ischial scars, the rectangular shape of the posterior lobe of the plastron, and the absence of an anal notch. (Fig. 15 ).

The scutes that were recovered are mostly rectangular in shape and they are ornamented with deep pits and a medial ridge in dorsal view (Fig. 15) . In ventral view the osteoderms are flat. The osteoderms range in size from 3 to 17 mm.

Discussion.-The skull tables match the description and illustration of Brachychampsa montana by Norell et al. (1994) . The supraoccipital fenestra of Brachychampsa montana is enlarged in the Hell Creek specimen. In Albertochampsa langstoni, the supraoccipital fenestra is elliptical in shape but rounded in Leidyosuchus canadensis (Erikson, 1972) .
The shape of the supraoccipital fenestra of SEPCP 1/654 is enlarged as in Brachychampsa montana. The frontal bone does not take part of the rim of the temporal fenestra in Brachychampsa.
Bulbous and low crowned teeth are usually referred to Brachychampsa montana.
There are some uncataloged specimens in the Desert Museum collection with these characteristics.
Rectangular scutes that have small facets for overlapping adjacent scutes are typical of the dorsal region. Dorsal osteoderms are keeled in some alligatorids such as Brachychampsa (Brochu, 1999) .
Family GAVIALOIDEA Genus Indet.
Locality.-Porvenir de Jalpa, General Cepeda, Coahuila, Mexico.
Referred Specimen.-SEPCP 61/743 partial skull.
Description.-SEPCP 61/743 is a partial skull including the anterior section of a snout of a longirostrine crocodyliform. The portion of snout includes the anterior part of maxilla.

In ventral view there are four alveoli, two on each maxilla. The alveolar diameter is 10 mm. The teeth are thecodont, with wide interalveolar space. The spaces between the teeth are scalloped so the dentary teeth would have interdigitated with the maxillary teeth ( Fig. 15 H-K) .

Discussion. Thoracosaurus neocesariensis from France (Carpenter, 1983; Brochu, 2004 Laurent et al., 2000 . Thoracosaurus macrorhynchus is from the early Paleocene of Europe (Storrs and Efimov, 2000; Brochu, 2004) . Meanwhile, other gavialoids include the Maastrichtian and Paleocene Ocepesuchus eoafricanus and Argochampsa krebsi from
Morocco (Hua and Jouve, 2004; Jouve et al., 2008) and the primitive North American genus Eosuchus (Brochu, 2006) .

The rostrum of SEPCP 61/743 shows separation of the premaxillae and nasals from the dorsal surface. In Thoracosaurus neocesariensis, the nasals extend far forward, almost to the maxillae (Carpenter, 1983) . In the Paleocene Argochampsa krebsi the nasal bones are fused and separate the maxillae to contact the premaxillae (Hua and Jouve, 2004) .

SEPCP 61/743 has a scalloped border on the maxilla. A scalloped border of the maxilla occurs in Argochampsa kresbi. This condition is also observed in Eosuchus (Hua and Jouve, 2004; Brochu, 2006; Jouve et al., 2008) . Eusuchus is younger and more primitive than Eothoracosaurus as shown by Jouve et al. (2008) Referred Specimen.-SEPCP 9/699, and 9/785 isolated teeth

Description.-In occlusal view the worn surface of SEPCP 9/699 and 9/785 ( Fig.16 ) lacks the characteristic pentagonal shape of the crown observed in hadrosaurian teeth. In contrast, the tooth crown has a strong median ridge and lacks serrations, as in ceratopsians.

Discussion. Description.-The wear facets on SEPCP 47/745 suggest that this tooth was from the lower jaw. It has small serrations in the anterior carina, is laterally compressed, and the cross section is oval. SEPCP 9/644 has denticles on the anterior carinae, and the denticles are chisel-like. SEPCP 61/729 is a pedal claw 2 cm long. The claw is laterally compressed and the distal end is incomplete. The proximal part it is 1.3 long and 7 mm wide. The tip is reduced and measures only 5 mm (Fig. 16 ).
Genus SAURORNITHOLESTES
Saurornitholestes sp.
Locality.-La Parrita SEPCP 9, El Pantano SEPCP 47
Referred Specimens.-SEPCP 9/624 and SEPCP 9/700 isolated teeth. Four manual claws SEPCP 9/726, 9/731, 9/626, and one pedal claw SEPCP 16/725.
Description.-The position of the teeth cannot be assigned to the dentary or the maxilla.

SEPCP 9/624, and SEPCP 9/700 are blade-like and strongly laterally compressed (Fig.   16 ). In SEPCP 9/624, the large denticles are located on the posterior carina and absent on the anterior carina. In SEPCP 9/700 there are 4 denticles/mm. The denticles are more sharply pointed than in Dromaeosaurus.

All unguals referred to Saurornitholestes from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation are strongly laterally compressed. The strong curvature in SEPCP 9/626 suggests a manual ungual. SEPCP 16/725 has a strong tubercle, and the body is straight as observed in pedal claws.

Discussion.-The teeth of Saurornitholestes have a blade-like crown that is unique in having a crown that is strongly laterally compresed. The denticles are more sharply pointed than in Dromaeosaurus (Currie et al., 1990) . Recently, two unnamed species have been recognized in the Aguja Formation based in isolated teeth (Sankey et al., 2005 ). The specimens from the Cerro del Pueblo differ from Saurornitholestes langstoni and from those from the Aguja and lower Tornillo formations in the higher degree of lateral compression (Fig. 16 ). The saurornitholestid unguals are distinctive for being strongly laterally compressed. They differ from dromaeosaurid unguals in the shape of the articular surface, presence of a strong tubercle, curvature, and in being strongly laterally compressed.
Family TROODONTIDAE
Troodon sp.
Locality.-La Parrita, General Cepeda, Coahuila, Mexico.
Referred Specimen.-SEPCP 9/778 isolated tooth.

Description.-SEPCP 9/778 is referred to Troodon because of the large hooked denticles with a rounded base and pointed tips and the wide interdenticular gap. The material is a fragmentary tooth with the tip missing. The tooth has large and pointed denticles visible on the preserved carinae, with a count of 2.5 denticles/mm (Fig.18 C-D) . The interdenticle spaces are pronounced. The shape and size of the denticles in SEPCP 9/778 differs from denticles observed in teeth referred to Dromaeosaurus sp., Saurornitholestes sp., and Richardoestesia sp., previously described from the Cerro del Pueblo. Among the Tyrannosauridae the number of denticles is also 2 to 3 denticles/mm. However the denticles along the carina are stout, large and well spaced resembling columns. In posterior view the denticle apices in tyrannosaurid teeth are round in outline. The denticles in Troodon have wide bases and the apices are labiolingualy compressed.

Discussion.-Teeth of small theropods have been identified to generic and specific level (Currie et al., 1990; Baszio, 1997) . Troodon teeth have the largest and most strongly hooked denticles and rounded denticle base of any theropod (Baszio, 1997 Description.-SEPCP 47/777 is a well preserved, small (3.5 mm length), recurved tooth.

The tooth is laterally compressed and has a narrow basal cross section. Denticles on the anterior carina and are considerably smaller than posterior denticles. The individual denticles in the posterior carina are short, rectangular, and closely packed. There are 9 denticles/mm on the posterior carina of SEPCP 47/777 ( Fig. 18 A-B ).
Discussion.-Ricardoestesia gilmorei was erected by Currie et al. (1990) (Sankey et al. 2005) , but they also occur in the Judith River Group.

SEPCP 47/777 compares well with Richardoestesia gilmorei, which is small and has minute denticles on the anterior carina and larger denticles on the posterior carina (Currie et al. 1990 ). Sankey et al. (2002) pointed out that there are 5 to 11 denticles/mm in the posterior carina. The variation is related to the size of the tooth. In SEPCP 47/777 the size of the tooth and the number of denticles are within this range. The absence of R.

isosceles in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation may be due to preservation and collecting and not related to ecological factors since both species of Richardoestesia occur in Dinosaur Provincial Park and the Aguja Formation (Sankey, 2001; Sankey et al. 2002) .
Infraorder CARNOSAURIA (Fig. 18 E-H) . They are large, stouter and more robust than other theropod teeth found at la Parrita microsites.

They are laterally compressed, and have an oval shape in cross section at the base of the tooth. Denticles occur on both the anterior and posterior carinae, and they are 0.6 mm long, and 0.4 mm wide. Their tips are round in outline, not pointed. On average, there are 2 denticles/mm. There are spaces between denticles and distinctive blood grooves.

SEPCP 47/742 has an anterior serrated cutting edge that shows considerable posteromedial displacement and it has a rounded surface anteromedially. It has a Dshaped cross section. SEPCP 47/742 is a premaxilary tooth (Fig. 18 I) .

Discussion.-The average size of the teeth, the shape and number of denticles per millimeter, the blood grooves and the transverse shape of teeth are distinctive characters used to diagnose the Tyrannosauridae (Currie et al. 1990; Sankey, 2001 ). The number of denticles found in tyrannosaurid teeth recovered from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation is consistent with the number observed in large tyrannosaurid species. The morphology of these teeth confirms the presence of the family in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation.

Genus Saltillomimus gen nov. Description.-The type specimen is an associated partial skeleton recovered in place from the contact between a shale and sheet sandstone. The elements of the type specimen were found in close association. The material, although disarticulated, is well preserved and undistorted. The type specimen is considered to be an adult because of the degree of ossification of the elements, and the presence of the characteristic small tubercle on the femur head, a feature that has been interpreted as indicative of adult individuals (Osmólska et al., 1972) . A partial foot of a juvenile individual was also recovered at this locality. As with the type specimen, these elements were disarticulated but preserved in close proximity to one another. Surface collected elements indicate that at least four additional individuals were preserved in this unit. In addition to the specimens from the La Majada locality, a partial femur has been collected from La Parrita locality.

The vertebral column of Saltillomimus rapidus is represented by four proximal caudal vertebrae (Fig. 20) . The most anterior of these is nearly fully preserved. It has a spool-shaped centrum and is weakly procoelous. Both articular surfaces are subcircular in outline. The posterior edge of the centrum preserves the articular facets for the chevrons and a small ridge along its ventral surface. This ridge ends between a subtriangular, shallow depression formed by the articular surfaces for the chevrons.

The neural arch, which is coossified with the centrum, preserves both pre-and postzygapophyses, a complete right diapophysis and part of the neural spine. The The hind-limb is nearly fully documented. The femur is represented by the right element of the type specimen and by SEPCP 9/770, which consists of the distal end of a left femur (Fig. 19 B, G) . The femur is a robust and short. The total length of the femur is 37 cm, and the circumference midway along the shaft is 13.5 cm. In lateral view, the femur is sigmoidal in shape. The femur head bears a small tubercle on its caudal surface, a feature that has been interpreted as indicative of an adult stage of development (Osmólska et al., 1972) . The lesser trochanter is wing-like in shape. The greater trochanter is not separated from the head. A small ridge located in the caudomedial surface of the shaft represents the fourth trochanter. The fossa for the caudofemoralis muscle is well developed on the medial surface of the shaft close to the fourth trochanter (Fig. 19 B) .

The shaft is almost square in cross section and is robust. (Fig.19 C) . The shaft of the tibia preserves a sharp ridge along its anterolateral surface. This ridge would have articulated with the fibula. The distal portion of the shaft becomes flattened anteroposteriorly.

The fibula is represented by the proximal end of the right and the distal end of the left fibula. The proximal end is expanded anteroposteriorly. In proximal view it has a deep groove for the articulation with the tibia. The shaft is thin and narrows to become thin distally. From the two partial fibulae, the total length of the fibula can be estimated to be 45 cm (Fig. 19 D) .
The pes of the type specimen is represented by metatarsals II, III and IV.

Metatarsal II it is robust and straight (Figs 19, 21) . Discussion.-Ornithomimosauria is a clade of medium-to-large sized Cretaceous theropods from the Northern Hemisphere (Barsbold and Osmólska, 1990) . This group of dinosaurs first appears in the Early Cretaceous (Pérez-Moreno et al., 1994) and radiated during the Late Cretaceous (Nichols and Russell, 1981) . Ornithomimosaurians include all bullatosaurs closer to Ornithomimus than to Troodon (Holtz, 1994 a, b) .

Ornithomimosauria are the sister-group of Troodontidae and both belong to Maniraptora (Pérez-Moreno et al., 1994) . Later Holtz (2000) and Padian et al. (1999) Kinnareemimus is the only ornithomimid recognized from Thailand and represents the oldest record of this group of theropods (Buffetaut et al., 2009) . Other occurrences in Asia include the primitive Harpymimus, Garudimimus, and the derived forms Archaeornithomimus, Anserimimus, and Gallimimus (Osmólska et al., 1972; Barsbold 1981 Barsbold ,1983 Barsbold , and 1988 Barsbold and Perle, 1984; Barsbold and Osmólska, 1990; Smith and Galton, 1990; Makovicky and Norell, 1998) . In addition, the genera
Sinornithomimus (Kobayashi et al., 1999; 2001, Kobayashi and Lü, 2003) and
Shenzhousaurus (Ji et al., 2003) have recently been described. In Europe Pelecanimimus is the only ornithomimid recognized (Pérez-Moreno et al., 1994; Makovicky et al., 2004) .

The Jurassic Elaphrosaurus bambergi (Janensch, 1920; Barsbold and Osmólska, 1990) from the Kimmeridgian beds of Tendaguru, Tanzania, was initially referred to the Ornithomimidae but is now considered to be an alvarezsaurid. An Asian origin for this group is suggested due to the distribution and diversity of the oldest record of ornithomimids (Buffetaut et al., 2009) .

The temporal distribution of ornithomimids in North America ranges from the Late Campanian to Late Maastrichtian and includes Ornithomimus, and Struthiomimus (Marsh, 1890; Osborn, 1916; Parks, 1926 Parks, , 1928 Parks, , 1933 Sternberg, 1933; Russell, 1972; Nicholls and Russell, 1981, 1985; Currie, 1987) . These are represented by articulated specimens. A third unnamed genus based on isolated elements from Alberta, Canada, has been reported (Longrich, 2008) . Reports of the family from mid-and southern latitudes of North American include cf. Ornithomimus edmontonicus from the Fruitland Formation, and cf. Struthiomimus altus and Ornithomimus antiquus from the Kirtland Formation, San Juan Basin, New Mexico (Lucas et al., 1987; Sullivan, 1997) . Remains of Ornithomimus velox were recovered in the Denver Formation of Colorado (Marsh, 1890) . Taxa recovered from the Kaiparowits Formation in Utah include cf.

Ornithomimus antiquus (= O. velox) (DeCourten and Russell, 1985; Hutchinson et al., 1998) . Ornithomimid indet. is reported from the Aguja Formation in the Big Bend area (Lehman, 1982; Davies, 1983 Park Formation, this ratio ranged from 3.3 to 3.5.

The increased robustness of the femur is not accompanied by a difference in proportions of the femur relative to crus length. The length of the femur in Saltillomimus is 37 cm, and the length of the crus, as indicated by the length of the fibula, is 45 cm.
Thus the femur is 20% shorter than the length of the crus. This is within the range of proportions seen in other ornithomimids (Osmólska, 1997) .

The metatarsus of Saltillomimus rapidus is distinctive in that the fourth metatarsal is strongly curved and diverges from the third. As discussed above this feature is present in both specimens that preserve a fourth metatarsal, and thus is interpreted as a natural America. Further material allowing a phylogenetic analysis of relationships of Saltillomimus rapidus will be necessary to resolve these two alternatives. In either case,
Saltillomimus contributes further support for latitudinal differentiation of dinosaur assemblages in North America (Lehman, 1997) .

The length of the femur relative to the crus indicates that Saltillomimus is not significantly different in cursoriality from those of other ornithomimids, suggesting that it was equally well adapted for rapid locomotion. However, the distinctive features of the femur and foot suggest that some aspects of the hind limb function of Saltillomimus differed from those of other ornithomimids. The hind limb of Saltillomimus differs from that of other ornithomimids in that the femur is more robust and the toes are more strongly splayed. These features may reflect a response to rapid locomotion on a soft substrate. The Cerro del Pueblo Formation represents sediments deposited in a wet environment, with high sedimentation rates (Eberth et al., 2004 Discussion.-This specimen, which is from the uppermost part of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, is thought to be a second ornithomimid taxon because it is much larger than the specimens of Saltillomimus. This difference is thought to be significant because Description.-SEPCP 47/377 is an incomplete right lower premolar of a multituberculate because it has a LP4 with a crown laterally compresed and trenchant. It measures 5.9 mm wide, and an estimated 6 mm long (Fig. 22 A) . In labial view four lateral ridges are observed. In lingual view six ridges are clearly distinguished. The crown is laterally compressed and it is trenchant. The border of the triangular crown is lost. Part of the dentary bone is preserved. The root of P 4 is not visible and P 3 is absent.

Discussion.-The presence of blade-like lower premolars with multiple serrations is a derived character among Multituberculata (Simpson, 1993) . The small number of lateral ridges is an apomorphic character for the Plagiaulocoidea. Because of its size, the triangular shape of the crown, and the low number of ridges, this specimen is tentatively assigned to the Family Taeniolabididae within the superfamily Taeniolabidoidea (Clemens and Kielan-Jaworowska, 1979; Kielan-Jaworowska and Horum, 2001 ).

The multituberculates were the most diverse mammals during the Late Cretaceous. They had a wide distribution on Holarctic continents. However, in Mexico there has been only a single report for this group, from the El Gallo Formation, Baja

California Norte (Lillegraven, 1972) . That material included an M 1 , M 2 and M 1 of Mesodma cf. formosa (Ectypodontidae). An M 2 and I 2 were assigned to the genus ?Stygymys (Eucosmodintidae). Two fragmentary P 4 s were also recovered from this formation, but their taxonomic assignment was not given (Lillegraven, 1972) . The El Pantano microfossil site produced the first multituberculate tooth from mainland northern Mexico.
Family CIMOLOMYIDAE Genus et sp. indet.
Locality.-La Parrita, General Cepeda, Coahuila, Mexico.
Referred specimens.-SEPCP 9/585 isolated M 2 .

Description.-SEPCP 9/585 is an isolated M 2 that preserves two roots (Fig. 22 B-D) . In the crown three rows of pyramidal cusps are observed. A small portion of the anterior part of the crown is lost but the cusp formula is 2:3:2. The cusps of the medial row are large, and crescentic. The molar is ornamented by grooves. This specimen was recovered by screening.
Discussion.-In Cimolomyidae the molar cusps are crescentic (Kielan-Jaworowska and Horum, 2001) . This condition is observed also within the Paracimexomys group.

Cimexomys and Paracimexomys have crescentic cusps Montellano, 1992) . Kielan-Jaworowska and Horum (2001) use the prescence of crescentic molar cusps in the Cimolomyidae as a derived character. In SEPCP 9/585 the molar cusps are well separated, pyramidal and crescentic. SEPCP 9/585 is tentatively assigned to the Cimolomyidae.

In Cimexomys there are differences in the size of the molar cusps of M 2 and the cusps are pyramidal and mostly subcrescentic (Montellano, 1992) . Stongly crescentic molar cusps in lower molars are observed in Cimolomys clarki , however pyramidal and subcrescentic molar cusps occur on M 2 (Montellano, 1992) .
Supercohort MARSUPIALIA Cohort ALPHADELPHIA Family PERADECTIDAE Genus TURGIDODON Turgidodon cf. T. russelli
Locality.-La Parrita, General Cepeda, Coahuila, Mexico.
Referred specimens.-Right dentary (SEPCP 9/715) with P 3 , M 1 , M 2 and space for M 3 .

Description.-The overall morphology of the teeth suggest didelphid affinities. The length of P 3 -M 3 is 13 mm. The depth of mandible below M 1 is 6.4 mm. The posterior mental foramen is located below the posterior root of M 1 . These tooth measurements suggest that SEPCP 9/715 was a medium size marsupial. P 3 is two-rooted, and has a single main cusp. The main cusp is trenchant with a high crown that exceeds the length of the tooth. The anterior edge of the main cusp is slightly convex. The posterior basal cusp is small and close to the main cusp. M 1 is smaller in size compared to M 2 . The trigonid size is reduced compared to the talonid. The protocone is the tallest cusp of the trigonid. The metaconid and paraconid are about the same height. The talonid is wide compared to the trigonid. The posterior side of the dentary exposes the posterior root of M 3 (Fig. 23) .

Discussion.-The posterior mental foramen is located below the posterior root of M 1 as observed in Alphadon and Turgidodon (Lillegraven and McKenna, 1986) . SEPCP 9/715 is larger than A. halleyi. It also differs in that SEPCP 9/715 has a massive ramus but gracile teeth as observed in T. russelli (Fox, 1979) . The main cusp of P 3 is less convex anteriorly in A. marshi (Lillegraven, 1969) compared to SEPCP 9/715. In SEPCP 9/715, the main cusp of P 3 is less convex anteriorly as observed in T. praesagus and its contemporary A. marshi, but not straight as A. halleyi from the Mesaverde Formation ( (Lillegraven and McKenna, 1986) (fig. 11, page 30) ). The occurrence of Turgidodon represents the first report from the Cretaceous in Mexico.
Family PEDIOMYIDAE Genus PEDIOMYS
Pediomys cf. P. elegans
Locality.-La Parrita, General Cepeda, Coahuila, Mexico.
Referred specimens.-SEPCP 9/716 right dentary with M 1 , M 2 preserved and alveoli for P 2 , and P 3 .

Description.-Length of P 3 -M 3 is 13 mm. SEPCP 9/716 is slender compared with the dentary referred to Turgidodon (SEPCP 9/715). The dentary at the level of the mental foramina in SEPCP 9/715 is 7 mm in depth, whereas SEPCP 9/716 is 5.1 mm. The mental foramen is located below of the posterior root of M 1 . Proximally, a small foramen is present at the position of P 2 . The premolars are double rooted. P 2 alveoli are distinctly smaller compared to P 3 . P 2 has a partially exposed anterior root, and a posterior small alveolus is observed. There are two large and deep alveoli for P 3 . Only the labial halves of M 1 and M 2 are preserved, and they are damaged. M 1 is distinctly smaller than M 2 (Fig.   23 ). On both molars the trigonid and talonid are notably different in size. The hypoconulid and entoconid are twinned.

Discussion.-The Pediomydae has a wide distribution in North America. Pediomys is also known at El Gallo Formation, Baja California, Mexico from a single tooth, M 1 (Clemens, 1979; Lillegraven, 1972) . In Pediomys florencae, P 3 is longer than either M 1 or P 2 and has two dental foramina. In P. hatchery, P 3 is slightly smaller than M 1 and slightly larger than P 2, and it has only one mental foramen (Clemens, 1966; Hunter and Pearson, 1996) . In SEPCP 9/716 the mental foramen is located below of the posterior root of M 1 as in Pediomys florencae, P. hatchery and P. elegans. Both premolars are two rooted, a major difference between them is the larger size estimated for P 3 as observed in
Pediomys florencae.
Family indet.
Locality.-Rincon Colorado, General Cepeda, Coahuila, Mexico.
Referred Specimen.-SEPCP 18/698, right dentary.

Description.-The relatively massive dentary preserves the canine, first premolar and roots for P 2 and P 3 . Length of P 3 -M 3 is 5 mm. A mental foramina is located below P 1 . P 1 has two roots. The anterior border of the crown in P 1 is projected posteriorly. The tooth is set obliquely in the dentary. In occlusal view the dentary shows that P 2 is slightly smaller than P 3 and larger than P 1 . The base of the canine is thick and not vertical ( This was originally proposed from study of the mammalian assemblages from by Cifelli, (1994) .

In addition to published descriptions of material from the Aguja and Javelina formations (Davies, and Lehman, 1989; Lehman, 1989a, c; Sankey, 2001; Sankey and Gose, 2001; Sankey et al., 2005) , material in the collections of the Vertebrate Paleontology lab of the University of Texas at Austin was examined.
The Tornillo basin it is located southwest Texas, USA. Much of the basin is included within Big Bend National Park, and the area is generally referred to as the Big

Bend area of Texas. The Parras and Tornillo basins are separated from each other by 400 km. They where formed under different tectonic settings and probably had different deltaic geometry, although deposition, facies, and lithology are similar (McBride et al., 1974; Lehman, 1985) .

The formations of Campanian to Maastrichtian age in the Tornillo basin are the Pen, Aguja and Javelina formations (Maxwell et al., 1967; Lawson, 1975; Davies, 1983 , Standhardt, 1986 Lehman, 1985 Lehman, ,1989c (Fig. 25 ).

The Pen Formation crops out extensively within the Big Bend. It consists of two units of calcareous marine shale and claystone. The basal member represents deposition on a marine shelf environment. The Makinney Spring Tongue of early to middle Campanian age (Lehman, 1985) intertongues with the Aguja Formation. The Pen Formation is correlative with San Carlos Formation in the Ojinaga Basin, west Texas, and with the middle Shale member of the Aguja Formation (Lehman, 1985 (Lehman, , 1989c .
Lithology and sedimentary facies of the Pen Formation have been correlated with the lower Parras Formation in Coahuila (Lehman, 1989c) . The Pen Formation has prodeltaic to delta front facies.

The Aguja Formation was named by Adkins (1933) . It is exposed in the Big Bend area of west Texas. The formation consists of 360 m of mudstone and sandstones with some interbedded lignites and rare freshwater limestones. The formation was deposited in a paralic environment with fluvially dominated deltaic processes (Davies, 1983; Standhart, 1986) . The depositional environments include small lakes, interpreted to be similar to those now seen in the modern Guadalupe delta. However, the paleosols and paleocaliche in the Aguja Formation suggest cyclic, seasonal and semi-arid environments (Lehman, 1989b , 1990 : Sankey, 1998 .

The contact between the Aguja and Pen Formation is gradational. The marine invertebrates of the Aguja Formation suggest middle to late Campanian age in the lower part (Maxwell et al., 1967; Lehman 1982 Lehman , 1985 Davies, 1983) and Maastrichtian for the upper part of these units.

The contact with the overlaying Javelina Formation is defined as the top of the first sandstone after the appearance of varicolored clay. This contact is diachronous so a portion of the upper Aguja Formation is equivalent to the lower part of the Javelina (Lehman, 1985) .

The Aguja Formation is formally divided into six members (Lehman, 1985) (Fig.   25 ). The first two members, the basal sandstone and lower shale, are considered to be middle Campanian age. The faunal content of the third member, the Rattlesnake Mountain Sandstone (Lehman, 1985 (Lehman, , 1989c Deinosuchus (Maxwell et al., 1967; Lehman, 1985) . Exogyra and Inoceramus banuxemi invertebrates are common in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation (Kirkland and Aguillon, 1995 Formation (Wolleben, 1977) .

The upper member was deposited in a fluvial coastal plain environment (Lehman 1982 (Lehman , 1989c . Davies (1983) concluded that the river systems of the upper member were equivalent to the lower part of the Javelina (Lehman, 1985) .

The Maastrichtian Javelina Formation is composed of variegated clays with lenticular sand bodies and rare lacustrine limestones (Maxwell et al., 1967; Standhardt, 1986) . The base of the Javelina Formation is diachronous. It has two informal members (Lehman, 1985) , a lower sandstone member and upper mudstone member. The lower sandstone member contains remains of Alamosaurus sanjuanensis. The Alamosaurus fauna is considered to be late Edmontonian to Lancian in age (Lehman, 1985 (Lehman, , 1987 (Lehman, , 1990 Lehman et al., 2006) . This member is correlative with the El Picacho Formation in the Ojinaga Basin in Chihuahua Mexico (Lehman, 1989c) . The upper mudstone member contains a Paleocene mammalian fauna (Standhart, 1986) . The Javelina Formation was deposited by unrestricted meandering streams in a semiarid inland floodplain (Davies, 1983 : Sankey, 1998 . The paleosols and paleocaliche in the lower Javelina Formation suggest cyclic, seasonal and semi-arid environments (Lehman, 1989b , 1990 : Sankey, 1998 (Davies, 1983) . One exception is found with juvenile and adult ceratopsians that were disarticulated but not transported on an abandoned crevasse channel in the Aguja Formation (Lehman, 1982 (Lehman, , 1985 .
The fauna of the Aguja Formation is listed in ?Stegoceras, and the crocodyliform Deinosuchus riograndensis (Lehman 1982; 1989a, c; Davies, 1983; Lucas et al., 2006; Longrich et al., 2010) .

Microvertebrates are particularly important for understanding the full faunal diversity of Late Cretaceous nonmarine vertebrate assemblages. Microvertebrates of the Aguja Formation have been described by Standhart (1986) , Rowe et al. (1992) and Sankey (1998) Sankey, 1998) . Cifelli (1994) observed that some characteristic Judithian taxa from more northern North America are not represented in the Aguja, due perhaps to biogeographic differentiation and the high degree of endemism

The Running Lizard microvertebrate assemblage is Maastrichtian and similar to Lancian assemblages (Standhart, 1986) . Taxa The vertebrates of the Javelina Formation (Table 7) have been described by Davies and Lehman (1989) and Standhardt (1986) . Of the bones preserved in carbonate nodules in the Javelina, most of them are isolated or show evidence of trampling (Fiorillo, 1998) . The assemblage is characterized by the presence of the giant pterosaur the presence of 10 taxa (Rowe et al., 1992) . However, all Cerro del Pueblo lizards appear to be common to the Aguja formations. Turtles are abundant and diverse in both the Cerro del Pueblo and Aguja formations (Tomlinson, 1997; Brinkman and Rodriguez de la Rosa, 2006) .

body_text.text: The Aguja, Cerro del Pueblo, and Javelina formations provide data on the diversity communities of the Late Cretaceous in the southern region of North America.

One of the potential reasons for the faunal differences is a difference in age of the assemblages. These formations range from mid-Campanian to latest Maastrichtian. The Aguja Formation has been dated by volcanic ash as 73 mya (Sankey, 2001) . The Cerro del Pueblo Formation and Javelina Formation have both been dated by paleomagnetic studies. The Cerro del Pueblo Formation was deposited in Chron 32n, and thus is estimated to be 72.5 ma (Eberth et al., 2004) . The Javelina Formation was deposited during an interval of reversed polarity correlated with C31r and is estimated to be 69 mya (Lehman et al., 2006) . Some of the features in which the fauna and floras of these assemblages differ can be attributed to these differences in time. In particular, the presence of Tyrannosaurus rex, Torosaurus, and the pterosaur Questzelcoatalus northropi in the Javelina Formation but not the Cerro del Pueblo or Aguja formations may be because these taxa are restricted to the latest Maastrichtian. As well, the Cerro del Pueblo Formation was deposited under conditions of low slope and low energy. There is little evidence for deep rivers in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation.

Deinosuchus in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, could be a reflection of these environmental differences, while the differences in the plant communities could be responsible for the differences in herbivorous megafauna, particularly the absence of sauropods in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. However, the suggested close association of hadrosaurids with the "platanoid/icacinoid" and "Baileyan wood type I" (Wheeler and Lehman, 2000; Lehman and Wheeler, 2001 ) based on the distribution of these taxa in the Aguja Formation is also observed at the Cerro Del Pueblo, where hadrosaurids and hamamelids (Platanacea) are found together.

body_text.text: paleolatitude, so faunal differences may be associated with latitudinal differentiation of the vertebrate assemblages present in each unit. The distribution of longirostrine crocodiles suggests that they may be latitudinally restricted in its distribution west of the Interior Seaway. Although they are present in New Jersey east of the interior seaway (Carpenter, 1983) , west of the Interior Seaway they are only known from the Cerro de Pueblo Formation and the El Gallo Formation in North Baja California. Thus their absence in the Aguja Formation may be a reflection of the latitudinally restricted distribution.

FIGREF0.text: compared to SEPCP 9/717 and specimens of Parasaniwa and Paleosaniwa in the collection of The Royal Tyrrell Museum and other varanoid vertebra from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. Family VARANOIDAE Genus PALAEOSANIWA Palaeosaniwa cf. P. canadensis Locality.-La Parrita, General Cepeda Coahuila, Mexico. Referred specimens.-SEPCP 9/645, left humerus , SEPCP 9/633 and SEPCP 9/634 vertebrae Description.-A partial humerus and two isolated vertebrae indicate the presence of a third varanoid taxon in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. Two vertebrae referred to

FIGREF1.text: described a complete right humerus of Paraderma bogerti from the KUA-1 locality, Scollard Formation. These specimen has a distal end lacking both well-ossified condyles and an ectepicondylar foramen. SEPCP 9/645 is larger than Paraderma bogerti and it shows clearly the characters mentioned above. The ocurrence of Palaeosaniwa cf. P. canadensis in the Cerro del Pueblo extends the geographic distribution of this Judithian lizard. Rincon Colorado (SEPCP-18), La Parrita (SEPCP-9) and Las Aguilas (SEPCP-61) General Cepeda, Coahuila, Mexico. Referred specimens.-SEPCP 18/ 201, a well-preserved posterior trunk vertebra lacking the extremities of both postzygapophyses and the left prezygapophysis; SEPCP 18/202, mid-trunk vertebra; SEPCP 18/203-204, an anterior trunk vertebra and 6 fragments of ribs; SEPCP 18/205, a centrum; SEPCP 9/628, centrum of trunk vertebra, and SEPCP 61/732, trunk vertebra lacking the neural arch. Description.-At least three individuals of Coniophis sp. indet #1 are represented in the snake material collected from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. Specimens SEPCP 18/ 201 to 205 were recovered in close association in the Rincon Colorado area and are interpreted as parts of a single individual. SEPCP 8/201 is a posterior trunk vertebra. It is 5 mm from cotylar rim to the end of the condyle. The vertebra is procoelous, elongate, wide, and robust. The centrum is dorsoventrally compressed (3.3 mm wide; 2.5 mm high)

FIGREF2.text: SEPCP 18/203 and 204 are preserved together on a small block and include vertebrae in association with ribs (Fig. 11). The vertebrae are preserved close to one another but are not articulated. The slight differences in size and differences in the development of a keel on the ventral surface of the centrum confirm that they belong to different portions of the vertebral column. SEPCP 18/203 is interpreted as an anterior trunk vertebra. A hemal keel is present on the ventral surface of the centrum. The keel is low, oblanceolate (terminology of LaDuke, 1991) in shape, extending from the edge of the cotyle to just before the rim of the condyle. The ventral surface of the centrum is smooth. The neural spine is low and blunt. Features of the neural arch are obscured by the matrix. SEPCP 18/204 is interpreted as a posterior trunk vertebra. SEPCP 18/202 is a small block containing two partial vertebrae. One preserves the ventral surface of the centrum and half of the neural arch. The second preserves the condyle and the paradiapophysial surface. These two vertebrae are preserved in articulation. In dorsal view the centrum has a pair of subcentral foramina differing in size. The synapophyses show the parapophysial and diapophysial facets. The cotyle is oblique. The posterior border of the neural arch has a slight indentation. The zygantrum is deeply excavated. The hemal keel is flattened posteriorly and does not reach the condyle. The presence of a low hemal keel in SEPCP 18/202, suggests a more anterior vertebral position than SEPCP 18/ 204 or SEPCP 18/ 201.SEPCP 61/ 732 is an isolated vertebra from El Porvenier de Jalpa (also referred to as Las Aguilas locality). It was found on an anthill by a private collector, Fernando Rios, and donated to the museum. It lacks the neural arch, and a small portion of the oval cotylar rim is missing(Fig. 12, A-B). The transverse process is eroded. The specimen is wider (6.43 mm) than long (4.47 mm). The centrum does not seem to be tapered. The hemal keel forms a weakly developed ridge. Two subcentral foramen are present. The right subcentral foramen is larger. The condyle is slightly constricted and does not show a rim. Compared to the specimens from Rincon Colorado, the condyle of SEPCP 61/732 is more massive and rounded. Differences in size and shape of centrum and the presence of a ridge-like hemal keel is interpreted as a result of individual variation.

The carapace is oval in shape, and most of the bone is preserved. There are seven pairs of costal bones. The first costal is twice as long as the second costal. Costals 2 to 4 are subequal in length. FIGREF7.text: The preserved portion of the shaft is oval in cross section. The proximal end is expanded and is subtriangular in outline. It has a flat tarsal articulation. Medially it has a concave surface for articulation with metatarsal III. Metatarsal III is represented by the proximal and distal ends, with the proximal portion including much of the shaft. The element is slender but has an anteroposteriorly expanded proximal end. Metatarsal IV is complete. This element is strongly curved and concave laterally. Thus, in articulation, this metatarsal is strongly divergent from metatarsal III. The partial foot of the juvenile specimen (SEPCP 16/221) also includes a complete fourth metatarsal (21 F). As in the type specimen, the element is strongly concave and diverges from the third metatarsal when in articulation. Because these two elements have the same pattern of curvature, this feature is interpreted as a natural feature of the bone, rather than an artifact of preservation. The fossa for the intraosseous ligament on the lateral surface of the metatarsal is oval and relatively shallow. The lateral surface of the fourth metatarsal is smooth, suggesting that a fifth metatarsal was absent.The pes is represented by four phalanges and the tip of an ungual. The phalanges differ little from those of other ornithomimids. The preserved portion of the ungual suggests that, as in ornithomimids generally, it was triangular in shape, with a deep lateral grove and was flattened ventrally.

The absence of a fifth metatarsal, as indicated by the surface texture of the fourth metatarsal is a difference from Struthiomimus. Saltillomimus is similar to Ornithomimus in this feature.Although much of the skeleton remains unknown and it is not possible to undertake a cladistic analysis to determine its phylogenetic position within the Ornithomimidae, Saltillomimus rapidus is erected here as a new genus and species because Saltillomimus rapidus is clearly distinct from other North American ornithomimids. Suprisingly, in some of the features in which Saltillomimus differs from other North American ornithomimids, it is similar to Asian taxa, particularly Garudimimus, Gallimimus, and Sinornithomimus. These features are the presence of a narrow pubic boot with a relatively straight ventral margin. At present, it is uncertain whether this pubic boot shape is a primitive or derived feature for ornithomimids. If primitive, the similarity would indicate that primitive lineages of ornithomimids survived in southern latitudes of North America and in Asia while a derived group was present in higher latitudes of North America. If derived, the shared presence of features of the pubic boot in Saltillomimus and the Asian ornithomimids would support a relationship of these taxa and would thus add to the evidence for interchange between Asia and North

FIGREF11.text: FAUNA AND FLORA OF THE CERRO DEL PUEBLO, AGUJA, AND JAVELINA FORMATIONS The vertebrate assemblage of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation is of biogeographic significance because it is the most southerly well-documented Late Cretaceous nonmarine vertebrate assemblage known from North America. Vertebrates are represented by both articulated and isolated elements, and vertebrate microfossil localities are present. Ongoing studies of this assemblage have provided an understanding of the general composition of the fauna and relative abundance of taxa present. The fauna and flora of the Cerro del Pueblo is here compared to the fauna and flora of formations that are Campanian to Maastrichtian in age within the Tornillo Basin in southern Texas (particularly the Aguja and Javelina formations). These formations are contemporaneous with the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. Thus comparison of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation to this area presents a good opportunity to observe paleoecological differentiation among contemporaneous floras and faunas in southern North America during the Late Cretaceous. Differences may be related to differences in age of the assemblages being compared, differences in local environment, or the presence of differences in latitudinal distributions of the taxa present. Through this comparison, the hypothesis is that the Aguja vertebrate assemblage shows a higher degree of endemism.

Microvertebrate assemblages from the Javelina Formation have not yet been described.Comparison of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation with the Aguja and Javelina formationsA number of features in which the vertebrate assemblage the Cerro del Pueblo Formation differs from those of the Aguja and Javelina formations can be identified inTables 2, 5, 6 and 7. Fish assemblages of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation differ from the Aguja Formation in their abundant presence of the sawfish Schizorhiza stromeri and the presence of a Melvius chauliodous, a species of large size. The Aguja Formation has a high number of lepisosteid and amiid fishes compared to material recovered from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation. Amphibians of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation and the Aguja Formation are represented by both anuran and salamanders, Albanerpeton and Scapherpeton are the two species of salamander known to the Aguja. Albanerpeton is the most abundant salamander being represented by a number of maxilla and dentaries in the Aguja Formation. Meanwhile the Cerro del Pueblo has Lisserpeton and lacks Albanerpeton and Scapherpeton. The sample size of frogs on both formations remain small and the full range of taxonomic diversity is poorly understood. The lepidosaur assemblage of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation is striking in the abundance of snake specimens recovered. Squamata is represented by two species of Coniophys one of them new. The lizards are represented by five taxa in the Cerro del Pueblo (Tale 9). Conversely, lizards are better represented in the Aguja Formation with

FIGREF15.text: The assemblages differ in that baenids are absent in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, while two genera are present in the Aguja Formation. Meanwhile bothremydids are better represented in the Cerro del Pueblo with the occurrence of Chedigaii and Posadachelys. Another difference is the absence of kinosternids in the Aguja. The turtle assemblage of the Javelina Formation is less well known, but the assemblage is like that of the Aguja in including a baenid. Crocodile remains are abundant in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation with at least two taxa, a small alligatorine referred to Brachychampsa and a generically indeterminate longirostrine crocodile represented by snout fragments. A third taxon is probably present based on teeth of moderate size that were referred to the Goniophilidae by Rodriguez de la Rosa and Cevallos-Ferris (1998). The crocodile assemblage of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation differs from that of the Aguja Formation in the absence of the giant Deinosuchus and the presence of a longirostrine crocodile. Crocodiles are not known from the Javelina Formation. Pterosaurs are present in all three formations, but the pterosaurs of the Aguja and Cerro del Pueblo Formation are generically indeterminate. In the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, pterosaurs are represented by tracks and rare bones. All of the material indicates that the pterosaurs in this formation are smaller than the Javelina pterosaur, Quetzalcoatlus northropi. Comparison of the dinosaur fauna of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation with that of the Aguja and Javelina is limited because of low taxonomic resolution. However, a few features of note can be identified. Despite abundant material, sauropod remains have not been recovered from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation, while they are present in both the Agua and Javelina formations. The ceratopsian assemblages of the Cerro del Pueblo and Aguja formations are similar to one another in the presence of chasmosaurines and the absence of Torosaurus. Hadrosaurs are abundant in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation and both hadrosaurine and lambeosaurines are present. Cranial material allows the identification of a new genus Velafrons coahuilensis and of Kritosaurus sp.(Gates et al., 2007). The theropods of the Cerro del Pueblo Formation and Aguja Formation differ from the theropods of the Javelina in the absence of Tyrannosaurus rex. Elsewhere, T. rex is only present in Late Maastrichtian deposits, so its absence is likely a reflection of the difference in age of these formations. The absence of Richardoestesia isoceles in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation is likely a reflection of difference in sample size. In other respects, the assemblages are generally similar.

FIGREF16.text: Other differences in the fauna and flora of the Cerro del Pueblo and Aguja formations are likely the result of environmental differences. The Aguja Formation was deposited on a floodplain with unrestricted meandering streams. The climate was seasonally semiarid as indicated by paleosols and caliches. Plant fossils indicate the presence of large trees in the interfluvial areas(Table 3 and4). The Cerro del PuebloFormation was deposited in a wet environment with abundant standing water as reflected by the abundance of charophytes and general sedimentological features of the formation.

FIGREF17.text: with those of localities from further north. Through a broad comparison of the fauna of the two formations, a more regional overview is obtained. Differences in the faunal composition of the Cerro del Pueblo and Aguja formations indicate that paleocological complexity was present in southern regions of North America during the Late Campanian.
