TABREF12.text: ).The Cerro del Pueblo Coniophis sp. indet #1 is more complete than previously described material of the contemporaneous species Coniophis cosgriffi. The Mexican species differs from other species of Coniophis in that the roof of the neural arch in the posterior trunk vertebra is flat, the diapophyses are convex, and a strongly oblique keel reaches the condyle as is also the case in the Cerro del Pueblo species #1. This condition is different from the type species of Coniophis, C. precedens, in which a hemal keel is absent. The elevation of the neural spine is variable among the different species of Coniophis. It can be absent or represented by a low ridge. In the Cerro del Pueblo sp. indet #1, the neural spine is represented by a low ridge. This condition is similar to C. carinatus. However, it differs from that species in being much smaller and in the absence of an accessory process on the prezygopophyses.Thus, Coniophis sp. indet #1 from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation likely represents a new species. However, variation within trunk vertebrae makes it difficult to name a new taxon based only on isolated vertebrae (LaDuke, 1991). Pending the discovery of additional material, the Cerro del Pueblo Formation is not named formally. Specimen SEPCP 9/744 is distinctive in the presence of a strong condylar rim. This feature is not present in the specimens from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation assigned to Coniophis sp. #1 or in other Late Cretaceous species of Coniophis. Thus, this feature is interpreted as of taxonomic significance, and indicates the presence of a second species of Coniophis in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation and another distinct species of Coniophis. As with Coniophis sp. indet sp. #1, this species will not be named pending the discovery of additional material that more fully documents the variation along the vertebral column and ontogenetic changes in the structure of the vertebrae. TABREF13.text: All specimens have similar well-developed axillary and inguinal buttress scars with expanded ends that form pillar-like structures that extend between the carapace and plastron. This new taxon from Coahuila was discovered in marine beds and it is associated with marine fauna including cheloniid turtles, mosasaurs, and ammonites. Bothremydidae is a group with a wide distribution extending from the Albian to the Eocene in North and South America, Europe, Africa and India. It consists of four monophyletic groups: the tribes Kurmademydini, Cearachelyni, Bothremydini, and

TABREF14.text: ). Among the bothremydinies, Bothremys, and Chedighalii are well known from the Campanian and Maastrichtian and the tribe Taphosphyini is represented by the genus Taphrosphys of Paleocene rocks of North America. In Mexico, Bothremys-like material has been reported to the Cerro del Pueblo (Garcia and Reynoso, 2002). The latter agrees with a large Pleurodira that Brinkman and Rodriguez de la Rosa (2006) refer to as Pleurodire # 1. New material from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation confirms the occurrence of a second small bothremydid named here and provides new information about the shell morphology.

TABREF15.text: Referred specimens.-SEPCP 1/654 skull table, two frontal bones SEPCP 1/724, SEPCP 9/731 and SEPCP 9/594 premaxillary teeth, SEPCP 9/593 lateral teeth and SEPCP 9/602 and SEPCP 9/603 isolated scutes.Description.-In dorsal view, the skull table (SEPCP 1/654) shows a suture in the midline of the parietals. The left fenestra supratemporalis is completely preserved. The lateral edge of the right fenestra is missing. The fenestra supratemporalis is oval and anteroposteriorly elongated. The fenestra is 16 mm long and 10.5 mm in width. The width of the fenestra is about equal to the interfenestral bar. The fenestra is surrounded by the postfrontal, squamosal and the parietal bones. The suture between the parietals and frontal is visible. The surface of the frontal is flat, it lacks a midline ridge and is separated from the fenestra by a short distance(Fig. 15). Two additional frontals SEPCP 1/724 and SEPCP 9/731 have been recovered from other localities, they are about the same size, broad posteriorly and broken anteriorly. The dorsal surfaces are heavily sculpted, flat and lack a midline ridge.In ventral view, SEPCP 1/654 from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation preserves one posterior maxillary bulbous tooth. The tooth is complete is approximately 1.8 cm long.It has a long root 1.3 cm and the crown is 5 mm high with finely wrinkled enamel. In occlusal view the tooth is nearly circular. Microvertebrate sites in the Cerro del Pueblo Formation commonly produce scutes, teeth and postcranial material of. Two different kinds of teeth are here assigned to Brachichampsa. TABREF21.text: Saltillomimus rapidus gen. et sp. novEtymology: The species name is derived from the Spanish word rapido, and refers to the interpretation based on proportions of the limb elements that this ornithomimid was a fast runner compared to other ornithomimids. An ornithomimid differing from all other North American ornithomimids in that the shaft of the pubis is straight, pubic boot extends more posteriorly than anteriorly and has an almost straight ventral edge, in contrast to the convex, massive pubic boot of Ornithomimus, and Struthiomimius. The femur differs from that of Ornithomimus and

TABREF22.text: ). All reports of ornithomimids from southern latitudes of North America are based on isolated elements. Considering the scarcity and fragmentary nature of ornithomimid material, the new discoveries of associated ornithomimid specimens from the Cerro del Pueblo Formation is of considerable significance and greatly increases our knowledge about ornithomimids in southern regions of NorthAmerica. rapidus is distinctive compared with the previously described ornithomimids in the shape of the pubis and features of the hind limb, particularly the femur. The pubis differs from that of other North American ornithomimids in that the pubic boot is shallow and has a straight ventral margin. Ornithomimus and Struthimimus, have a pubis with a deep pubic boot and a strongly curved ventral margin when seen in lateral view. Saltillomimus rapidus and the other North American taxa differ from the Asian taxon Archaeornithomimus in having a nearly straight pubis. In Archaeornithomimus, the shaft of the pubis is strongly curved. Gallimimus, Sinornithomimus and Garudimimus all have a pubic boot that is similar to Saltillomimus in being relatively shallow and having a nearly straight ventral edge. However, they differ in that the angle between the pubic boot and the shaft of the pubis is greater.The hind limb of Saltillomimus rapidus differs from that of other North American taxa in that the femur is relatively more robust. Relative size of the femur was estimated by comparing length to circumference measured along the midshaft region(Table 8). For comparison, four complete, uncrushed ornithomimid femora from the Late Cretaceous Dinosaur Park Formation of Alberta were measured. Although these femora cannot be identified to genus, they are similar in proportions to femora in articulated specimens of Ornithomimus, and Struthiomimus, and thus are assumed to be typical for this group of ornithomimids. The ratio of femur length divided by circumference in Saltillomimus rapidus was 2.7, whereas in the ornithomimid femora from the Late Campanian Dinosaur

TABREF23.text: ).
